page.title: 11Local History, Waternish
page.content: A point of local interest is Trumpan Church; dating to pre-Reformation times. The altar was at the east end. The congregation was Roman Catholic. On May 15 1578, while the people, who were of the Clan Macleod, were at worship, the thatched roof was set alight by members of the Clan Macdonald from Uist. This was a revenge attack. One woman escaped and raised the alarm. A battle ensued. Many Macdonalds were killed; so many in fact that they could not be buried separately. The bodies were lined up against a dyke, which was then knocked over on top of them. It was known as the Battle of the Spoilt Dyke. Buried here too is Lady Grange, sister-in-law of the Earl of Mar, who raised the Jacobite Rebellion in 1715. She, a Hanoverian, threatened to betray them.
